questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of chronic cough, sinus pain, and nasal discharge. He has a history of frequent upper respiratory infections and recurrent sinusitis since childhood. He is also concerned about fertility, as he and his wife have been trying to conceive for 5 years unsuccessfully. Pulmonary examination shows crackles and wheezing throughout both lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a defect in which of the following molecular structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dynein arm

 

This clinical scenario describes chronic respiratory infections, sinusitis, infertility, and a CT scan demonstrating dextrocardia (heart on the right side), most consistent with Kartagener syndrome (a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia). The disorder results from a defect in the dynein arm, a molecular motor protein essential for ciliary movement. Dysfunctional cilia lead to poor mucociliary clearance, recurrent infections, impaired fertility, and situs inversus (dextrocardia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and B. IL-12 receptor and IL-2R gamma chain: Related to immune deficiencies, not ciliary dyskinesia or situs inversus.

 

Option C. NADPH oxidase: Deficient in chronic granulomatous disease, presenting with recurrent catalase-positive infections but not situs inversus or infertility.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of sharp chest pain and a nonproductive cough. The pain worsens with deep inspiration and improves when he leans forward. Three weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction and underwent stent implantation of the right coronary artery. His temperature is 38.4째C (101.1째F) and blood pressure is 132/85 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation shows a high-pitched scratching sound during expiration. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Immune response to cardiac antigens

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for the same since a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Amiodarone

choices.text: Periductal concentric scarring and fibrosis
Periportal lymphocytic infiltration and piecemeal necrosis
Diffuse fibrosis with PAS-staining globules
Irregular ductal glands lined by atypical and pleomorphic cells

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his eyes, generalized fatigue, and pruritus. He was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 7 years ago. At the time of diagnosis, a PANCA test was also positive. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and multiple scratch marks on the trunk and extremities. Serum studies show a total bilirubin concentration of 3.2 mg/dL, direct bilirubin concentration of 2.5 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase level of 450 U/L. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography is shown below. Histologic examination of a liver biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Periductal concentric scarring and fibrosis

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic, hypertensive woman underwent a cardiac biopsy. Her histology image with special stain is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of blurry vision and fatigue for 2 months. During this period, he has also had occasional bleeding from his gums after brushing his teeth. One month ago, he was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis after returning from an overseas business meeting. His pulse is 118/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 149/91 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips. The tip of the spleen is palpable 1 cm below the left costal margin. Sensory examination of the hands shows paraesthesia. Hemoglobin concentration is 18 g/dL, haematocrit is 65%, leukocytes are 15,000/uL, and platelets are 470,000/uL. His serum erythropoietin concentration is decreased. Activation of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nonreceptor tyrosine kinase

 

JAK2 is a nonreceptor tyrosine kinase mutated in polycythemia vera, causing constitutive activation of signaling pathways that drive uncontrolled proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells independent of erythropoietin.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Receptor tyrosine kinase: These are membrane receptors with intrinsic kinase activity involved in other signaling pathways, not typically mutated in polycythemia vera.

 

Option B. Cytokine receptor: Cytokine receptors lack intrinsic kinase activity and function by associating with kinases like JAK2, so the receptor itself is not the active molecule here.

 

Option C. Antiapoptotic molecule: Polycythemia vera results from increased cell proliferation signaling rather than primary defects in apoptosis regulation.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, cough , weight loss, histology of the pathology is as shown below. What is the most likely cytokine involved?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Interferon gamma

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure was 146/91 mm Hg at his appointment 1 month ago; subsequent home blood pressure measurements have ranged from 135/83 mm Hg to 156/96 mm Hg. His blood pressure today is 141/85 mm Hg.  Pharmacotherapy with lisinopril is initiated. Administration of this drug is most likely to result in decreased activity of which of the following sections of a normal adrenal gland?
questions.solution: Ans. B) B

questions.text: A 46-year-old male with a history of depression has been treated with fluoxetine for the past six months. He presented to the emergency department with altered consciousness and an ECG showing QT prolongation, with a QTc of 447 ms. Recently, he was prescribed an additional medication for chronic pain management. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to his regimen that could have contributed to his current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Methadone

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police because of altered mental status. The police found him covering his ears and shouting near a highway rest area. Lab studies are shown:  Serum Na: 140 meq/l, Cl: 102 meq/l, pH: 7.39, PCO2: 31mm Hg, HCO3: 18meq/l. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Salicylate toxicity

choices.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis
Forced expiration against an open glottis
Forced inspiration against a closed glottis
Forced inspiration against an open glottis

questions.text: Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. His temperature is 37.2째C (99째F) and pulse is 105/min. When the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 140 mmHg, the patient's pulse is audible and regular. However, upon inspiration, the pulse disappears and does not reappear until expiration. Only when the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 125 mm Hg is the pulse audible throughout the entire respiratory cycle. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asthma

 

  • The clinical finding described is pulsus paradoxus, a greater than normal (>10 mm Hg) drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.
  • Pulsus paradoxus occurs when the systolic blood pressure falls so much during inspiration that the peripheral pulse disappears with the blood pressure cuff inflated to a certain level.
  • The causes of pulsus paradoxus include asthma, pericardial tamponade, and severe obstructive airway diseases.
  • In asthma, increased negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration exaggerates the normal inspiratory drop in blood pressure, causing pulsus paradoxus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral regurgitation: Does not cause pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option B. Lobar pneumonia: Usually causes fever and lung findings but not pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option C. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Causes outflow obstruction but not pulsus paradoxus.

questions.text: Which technique is used to identify auto antibodies?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Indirect immunofluorescence

choices.text: Gastric H+ increases, Duodenal HCO3 increased, Duodenal Cl- no change
Gastric H+ decreases, Duodenal HCO3 decreased, Duodenal Cl- no change
Gastric H+ decreases, Duodenal HCO3 increased, Duodenal Cl- decreases
Gastric H+ decreases, Duodenal HCO3 increased, Duodenal Cl- increases

questions.text: During a study on gastrointestinal hormones, a volunteer is administered the hormone secreted by S cells. Which of the following changes most likely represent the effect of this hormone on gastric and duodenal secretions?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Gastric H+ decreases, Duodenal HCO3 increased, Duodenal Cl- decreases

choices.text: ACTH-producing growth in the pituitary gland
Pleomorphic modified smooth muscle cells in the renal cortex
Involution of zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive fatigue and weakness. She also reports recurrent headaches for 2 years, which have increased in severity and frequency. Her blood pressure is 185/95 mm Hg. Serum studies show a morning renin activity of 130 ng/mL per hour (N=1-4), a morning aldosterone concentration of 60 ng/dL (N=5-30), and a potassium concentration of 2.9 mEq/L. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic modified smooth muscle cells in the renal cortex

 

Pleomorphic modified smooth muscle cells are characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia, a common cause of renovascular hypertension in young females. This leads to renal artery stenosis, resulting in increased renin and aldosterone secretion, causing hypertension and hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ACTH-producing growth in the pituitary gland: Causes Cushing disease, leading to cortisol excess, not elevated renin or aldosterone levels.

 

Option B. Increased urinary excretion of metanephrines: Indicative of pheochromocytoma, which causes episodic hypertension without significant renin or aldosterone elevation.

 

Option D. Involution of zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland: Would decrease aldosterone production, causing hypotension and hyperkalemia, not hypertension or hypokalemia.

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine
HBV infection in the remote past

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?

 

  • HBsAg - Negative
  • Anti HBs - Negative
  • Anti HBc IgM - Negative
  • Anti HBc total - Positive
  • HBeAg - Negative
questions.solution: Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the ECG shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Mobitz type 2 block

choices.text: Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase
Periodic acid- Schiff
Cluster of differentiation 1a

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening fatigue and recurrent bleeding from his gums for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows marked pallor. There are scattered red, nonblanching pinpoints spots on his trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 80,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 104,000/mm3. Genetic analysis of a bone marrow aspirate shows leukemic cells with a balanced translocation between the long arms of chromosome 15 and 17. These cells are most likely to stain positive for which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Myeloperoxidase

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Calcium influx

choices.text: Serum uric acid levels
Urinary calcium excretion
Urinary sodium excretion
Serum glucose levels

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after presenting with elevated blood pressure readings during her last two visits. After her last visit 2 months ago, she tried controlling her hypertension with weight loss before starting medical therapy, but she has since been unable to lose any weight. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 154/90 mm Hg on the right arm and 155/93 mm Hg on the left arm. She agrees to start treatment with a thiazide diuretic. In response to this treatment, which of the following is most likely to decrease?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Urinary calcium excretion

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 mmHg and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

 

  • In a patient with diabetes mellitus and hypertension, first-line antihypertensive therapy often includes calcium channel blockers (such as amlodipine) or ACE inhibitors/ARBs because they effectively manage blood pressure and reduce diabetic kidney disease progression.
  • Amlodipine (a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker) effectively lowers blood pressure and is well tolerated in diabetic patients.
  • Lifestyle modifications remain essential for overall cardiovascular health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Metoprolol  (beta-blocker): Not first-line in diabetes without specific indications such as ischemic heart disease or heart failure; beta-blockers may mask hypoglycemia symptoms.

 

Option B. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification: Insufficient given BP is 150/90 mm Hg, which requires pharmacological intervention.

 

Option C. Diet + Prazosin: Not first-line antihypertensive; generally reserved for resistant cases or specific indications.

 

Thus, combination of lifestyle changes and amlodipine is the best management.

choices.text: Pulsus parvus et tardus
Fixed splitting of S2
Water hammer pulse

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Water hammer pulse

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

The motor supply of the muscle spindle (shown in the image) is provided by gamma motor neurons, which innervate the intrafusal muscle fibers and regulate their sensitivity to stretch. This allows the muscle spindle to adjust and respond to changes in muscle length, contributing to proprioceptive feedback and reflex control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha neuron: Innervates extrafusal muscle fibers responsible for muscle contraction and generating force, not the muscle spindle itself.

 

Option C. Beta neuron: Innervates both intrafusal and extrafusal muscle fibers, but their role is less prominent compared to alpha and gamma neurons and not the primary motor supply for muscle spindles.

 

Option D. Delta neuron: This term is not commonly used to describe motor neurons in the somatic system; it is generally associated with sensory neurons or other classifications, thus not relevant here.

choices.text: Accumulation of hemoglobin in the intestine

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of increasing confusion and lethargy for the past 12 hours. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 108/67 mm Hg. Examination shows abdominal distention and several erythematous, lacy lesions on the chest that blanch with pressure. His hands make a flapping motion when they are dorsiflexed. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Accumulation of hemoglobin in the intestine


This clinical picture (spider angiomas, ascites, asterixis, altered mental status) is hepatic encephalopathy from advanced liver disease. Gastrointestinal bleeding (accumulation of blood/hemoglobin in the gut) is a classic precipitant because hemoglobin is broken down by gut bacteria to ammonia and other nitrogenous products that cross the damaged liverbrain axis, increasing neurotoxicity and precipitating encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated systemic vascular resistance: Not a precipitant of hepatic encephalopathy; vascular resistance changes relate to hemodynamics in cirrhosis but do not directly cause encephalopathy.

 

Option B. Destruction of gut anaerobes: Usually reduces ammonia-producing flora (and is therapeutic when achieved with rifaximin), so it would not precipitate encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Thiamine pyrophosphate deficiency: Causes Wernicke encephalopathy (ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confusion), a different syndrome without spider angiomas or asterixis and unrelated to hemoglobin accumulation.

choices.text: Follicular epithelial cell hyperplasia
Undifferentiated giant cells with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage
Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal follicle formation
Noncaseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of fever, anterior neck pain, and throat swelling. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and a fine tremor of the outstretched hands. The thyroid gland is enlarged, firm, and tender to palpation. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 65 mm/h. Iodine-123 scan shows an enlarged thyroid gland with diffusely decreased uptake. Histologic examination of a thyroid biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Noncaseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells

questions.text: 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive fatigue, cough, shortness of breath, and a 6.6-kg  weight loss. He used to work at construction sites. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. A CT scan of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion and circumferential pleural thickening with calcifications on the left hemithorax. Pathologic examination of a biopsy specimen of the thickened tissue is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A)

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Nelson syndrome occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy due to loss of cortisol feedback inhibition on the pituitary. This leads to enlargement of an existing ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, resulting in high ACTH levels and hyperpigmentation along with possible mass effects causing vision deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum pituitary infarction leading to hypopituitarism, typically without hyperpigmentation or vision loss.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Characterized by primary hyperaldosteronism causing hypertension and hypokalemia, not hyperpigmentation or vision problems.

 

Option D. Addison's disease: Primary adrenal insufficiency causing hyperpigmentation but not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

choices.text: PT increased, aPTT increased, Fibrinogen decreased, D-dimer normal
PT normal,  aPTT increased, Fibrinogen decreased, D-dimer increased
PT increased, aPTT normal, Fibrinogen normal, D-dimer normal
PT increased, aPTT increased, Fibrinogen decreased, D-dimer increased

questions.text: Four days after admission to the hospital for acute pancreatitis, a 41-year-old man develops hypotension and fever. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm extremities, asymmetric calf size, and blood oozing around his Iv sites. There are numerous small, red, non blanching macules and patches covering the extremities, as well as several large ecchymoses. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dl. A PBS shows schistocytes and decreased platelets. Which of the following sets of serum findings are most likely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) PT increased, aPTT increased, Fibrinogen decreased, D-dimer increased

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution: Ans. D) Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

choices.text: PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased
PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased
PTH decreased, vit D increased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased
PTH decreased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Medications include insulin, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Physical examination shows pitting edema of both ankles. Serum creatinine concentration is 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following sets of serum findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased

 

In chronic kidney disease, decreased renal conversion of vitamin D reduces calcium absorption, leading to hypocalcemia. Low calcium and phosphate retention stimulate parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion, causing secondary hyperparathyroidism with increased PTH, low vitamin D, low calcium, and high phosphate levels.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. PTH increased, vit D decreased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased: Incorrect because calcium is usually decreased, and phosphate is increased due to reduced excretion in CKD.

 

Option C. PTH decreased, vit D increased, Ca increased, Po4 decreased: Incorrect; PTH is typically elevated in CKD to compensate for hypocalcemia, while vitamin D levels are decreased.

 

Option D. PTH decreased, vit D decreased, Ca decreased, Po4 increased: Incorrect because decreased PTH does not occur in CKD; PTH is usually elevated in response to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure.
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure.
The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure.
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: The true statement among the following is:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, he attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Diltiazem

choices.text: Intracellular gram positive bacteria

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of intermittent watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. He has had a 12-kg weight loss during this period. He has also had episodic pain of the ankle, wrist, and knee joints during the past 5 years. An endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is performed. Histopathologic examination of a tissue specimen shows foamy macrophages in the lamina propria with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive inclusions. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Intracellular gram positive bacteria

choices.text: Peaked T waves

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and progressive peri-oral numbness for the past 24 hours. 3 days ago, he underwent a total thyroidectomy for treatment of papillary thyroid cancer. While measuring the patient's blood pressure, the nurse observes a spasm in the patient's hand. Physical examination shows a well-healing surgical wound on the neck. Which of the following ECG findings are most likely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) QT prolongation

choices.text: <5 g salt intake everyday
< 30% of the calories should come from fat

questions.text: A diabetic patient's fasting blood glucose level is found to be 160 mg/dL. What will you advise the patient regarding non-pharmacological management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) < 30% of the calories should come from fat

questions.text: Which of the following is useful for a patient having Haemophilia B?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fresh frozen plasma

 

  • Hemophilia B is caused by a deficiency of factor IX.
  • Fresh frozen plasma contains all clotting factors, including factor IX, making it useful for treating hemophilia B when factor IX concentrate is not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate: Cryoprecipitate contains mostly factor VIII, fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, and factor XIII, but very little factor IX, so it is not useful in hemophilia B.

 

Option C. Recombinant factor 8: Recombinant factor VIII is specifically for hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency).

 

Option D. Cryo poor plasma: Cryo-poor plasma (plasma minus cryoprecipitate) contains factors not in cryoprecipitate but is not typically used to treat hemophilia B.

choices.text: Induction of conformational change in antithrombin III
Reduced activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of palpitations and shortness of breath that started 3 days ago. She has hypertension and congestive heart failure. An ECG shows a narrow-complex tachycardia without P waves. The patient is prescribed a prophylactic medication that can be reversed with idarucizumab. The expected beneficial effect of the prescribed drug is most likely due to which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Direct inhibition of thrombin

 

  • The patient presents with atrial fibrillation (narrow-complex tachycardia without P waves), for which anticoagulation is required to prevent thromboembolism.
  • The medication mentioned is one that can be reversed with idarucizumab, which is a specific antidote for dabigatran.
  • Dabigatran is a direct thrombin (factor IIa) inhibitor, providing anticoagulation.
  • Other anticoagulants

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Induction of conformational change in antithrombin III: It is the mechanism of heparin.

 

Option B. Direct inhibition of factor Xa: Direct inhibition of factor Xa corresponds to drugs like rivaroxaban, apixaban.

 

Option C. Reduced activation of factors II, VII, IX, and X: It is the mechanism of warfarin.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intranuclear immuno-histochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumor?
questions.solution: Ans. D) INSM

questions.text: A 71-year-old, hospitalized man develops abnormal laboratory studies 4 days after starting treatment for exacerbation of congestive heart failure. He also has a history of osteoarthritis and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He recently completed a course of amikacin for bacterial prostatitis. Before hospitalization, his medications included simvastatin and ibuprofen. Blood pressure is 111/76 mm Hg. Serum studies show a creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL (previously normal) and a BUN of 48 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows a urine osmolality of 600 mOsm/kg and urine sodium of 10 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's renal insufficiency?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Volume depletion

choices.text: Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Altered cell shape

choices.text: Myosin heavy chain defect
GAA trinucleotide repeats

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of one year history of progressive shortness of breath. She is now unable to jog for more than 10 minutes without stopping to catch her breath. Cardiac examination shows a harsh systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. The murmur increases in intensity when she moves from a squatting to a standing position and decreases when she clenches her fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Myosin heavy chain defect

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Spironolactone

questions.text: Which of the following is not a growth factor promoting proto-oncogene?
questions.solution: Ans. D) TGF-beta

choices.text: Adverse effect of medication

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of irregular menses, milky discharge from her nipples, fatigue, and weight gain. Menses occur at irregular 25-40-day intervals and last 1-2 days with minimal flow. 5 months ago, she was started on clozapine for treatment of schizophrenia. She has hypothyroidism but has not been taking levothyroxine over the past 6 months. Visual field examination show no abnormalities. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone is 17.0 U/mL and serum prolactin is 85 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Hypothyroidism

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin
Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+
Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum
Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Hodgkin lymphoma (HL)?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

choices.text: IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies
Intraluminal esophageal membrane
Granulomatous inflammation of the terminal ileum

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 8-month history of fatigue, intermittent postprandial abdominal bloating and discomfort, foul-smelling, watery diarrhea, and a 7-kg weight loss. She developed a pruritic rash on her knees 3 days ago. Physical examination shows several tense, excoriated vesicles on the knees bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.2 g/dL. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies

questions.text: An 18-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, back pain, and dark-colored urine for two days. He recently sprained his ankle playing basketball and has been taking ibuprofen as needed for pain. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.2 g/dL and serum lactate dehydrogenase concentration of 354 U/L. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear with Wright's stain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely mode of inheritance for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) XLR

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the calorimetric test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

  • The RBC pipette is used for counting or measuring red blood cells and platelets counting, not for hemoglobin estimation.
  • The Sahli graduated hemoglobin tube, hemoglobin pipette, and comparator with brown glass standard are all components used in the Sahlis method for hemoglobin estimation by calorimetric (colorimetric) test.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with alcohol use disorder comes to the physician because of a fever and productive cough. An x-ray of the chest shows a right lower lobe consolidation and a diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia is made. The physician prescribes a drug that blocks peptide transfer by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Clindamycin

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is produced by:

 

1. Kidney
2. Liver
3. Spleen
4. Lung
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

  • EPO is mainly from kidney (peritubular interstitial cells), with minor fetal contribution from liver.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 1 only: Not fully correct as liver also contributes.

 

Option B. 2 only: Incorrect, kidney is main site.

 

Option D. 2, 3, 4: Spleen/lung dont produce EPO.

choices.text: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
Narrowing of the left main coronary artery

Symmetric thickening of the left ventricle

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after collapsing while playing basketball. He has no history of serious illness. On arrival, there is no palpable pulse or respiratory effort observed. He is declared dead. The family agrees to an autopsy. Cardiac workup prior to this patient's death would most likely have shown which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct sequence of events in cAMP signal transduction pathway?

 

1. Activation of adenylate cyclase

2. Activation of PKA

3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP

4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of gradually worsening fatigue, increased urinary frequency, and blurry vision for 5 months. Physical examination shows decreased vibratory sense and proprioception in the lower extremities. His HbA1c is 10.4%. Treatment for his condition with an appropriate medication is begun. In response to this drug, pancreatic islet cells begin producing increasing amounts of secretory granules. The patient was most likely treated with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Glimepiride

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. Cystoscopy shows several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. A biopsy specimen of the bladder masses shows moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. The patient most likely has a history of exposure to which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Aromatic amines

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

Metformin is commonly associated with gastrointestinal side effects, including unexplained diarrhea, due to its effects on intestinal absorption and motility. This is a well-known adverse effect often limiting its tolerability.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Primarily causes fluid retention and weight gain, with diarrhea being uncommon.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: May cause nausea and vomiting, but diarrhea is not a typical side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Sulfonylureas like glimepiride commonly cause hypoglycemia and weight gain, not diarrhea.

choices.text: Hyper IgM syndrome

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of headache and worsening vision. Ophthalmologic examination shows a visual acuity of 20/120 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 14.2 g/dL and total serum calcium of 9.9 mg/dL. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Serum electrophoresis shows increased concentration of a pentameric immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with fever, cough and tenacious white sputum. Which of the following should be used for treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Syrup Bromhexine

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband for lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days. She returned from a trip to Thailand 2 weeks ago. Her immunizations are up-to-date and she has never received blood products. Her temperature is 38.9째C (102째F). She is not oriented to person, place, or time. Examination shows jaundice and mild asterixis. Her prothrombin time is 18 sec (INR=2.0), serum alanine aminotransferase is 3911 U/L, and serum aspartate aminotransferase is 3724 U/L. This patient's current condition is most likely associated with increased titers of which of the following serum studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-HEV IgM

 

Clinical vignette summary

 

  • 33-year-old pregnant woman (24 weeks, G2P1)
  • Recent travel to Thailand (endemic area for Hepatitis E)
  • Acute illness: fever, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, altered sensorium, asterixis
  • Labs: markedly raised AST/ALT (>3000 U/L), prolonged PT/INR acute fulminant hepatitis

 

Confirms acute HEV infection.

 

Key clue

 

Pregnancy + Fulminant hepatitis + Endemic country (Asia) strongly suggests Hepatitis E virus (HEV).

 

  • HEV is transmitted fecalorally (contaminated water, food).
  • In pregnancy (especially 2nd/3rd trimester), it carries very high risk of acute liver failure & maternal mortality (up to 25%).
  • Diagnosis: Anti-HEV IgM positivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HBe IgM: marker of acute HBV replication, not seen here.

 

Option B. HBsAg: indicates HBV infection (chronic/acute), not consistent with pregnancy-related fulminant hepatitis.

 

Option D. Anti-HCV IgG: indicates past HCV exposure, not acute fulminant hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Evolocumab

choices.text: End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease
End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease
End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP no change, Contractility increase, HR decrease
End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP increase, Contractility decrease, HR no change

questions.text: A previously healthy 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of chest pain on exertion. She takes no medications. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac stress ECG shows inducible ST-segment depressions in the precordial leads that coincide with the patient's report of chest pain and resolve upon cessation of exercise. Pharmacotherapy with verapamil is initiated. This drug is most likely to have which of the following sets of effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease

 

  • Verapamil is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It has negative inotropic and chronotropic effects by inhibiting calcium channels in cardiac muscle and the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes.
  • Effects of verapamil include:
    • Increased end-diastolic volume (EDV): Due to decreased contractility and slower heart rate, allowing more ventricular filling.
    • Decreased blood pressure (BP): Through vasodilation of systemic arteries.
    • Decreased contractility: Negative inotropic effect.
    • Decreased heart rate: Negative chronotropic effect by slowing SA node firing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP decrease, Contractility decrease, HR decrease: EDV decreases with increased contractility, which verapamil decreases.

 

Option C. End diastolic volume (EDV) increase, BP no change, Contractility increase, HR decrease: BP generally decreases due to vasodilation, not increases.

 

Option D. End diastolic volume (EDV) decrease, BP increase, Contractility decrease, HR no change: HR decreases, not stays the same, from verapamil's SA node effects.

questions.text: All of the following drugs act as HER-1 inhibitors except
questions.solution: Ans. C) Pertuzumab

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Functional residual capacity

choices.text: Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased
Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone decreased
Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium decreased, Serum aldosterone increased
Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by staff of the group home where he resides because of worsening confusion for the past week. He has a history of major depressive disorder and had an ischemic stroke 4 months ago. Current medications are aspirin and sertraline. His pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist oral mucosa, normal skin turgor, and no peripheral edema. While in the waiting room, he has a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 119 mEq/L and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone concentration. Which of the following sets of additional laboratory is likely in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone decreased

 

  • This is SIADHlow serum osmolality, high urine sodium, and suppressed RAAS.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased: Wrong, dilutional hyponatremia decreases it.

Option C. Serum osmolarity increased, Urine sodium decreased, Serum aldosterone increased: Not SIADH.

 

Option D. Serum osmolarity decreased, Urine sodium increased, Serum aldosterone increased: Not possible, as RAAS is suppressed.

choices.text: Increased pulmonary vascular resistance

questions.text: A 19-year-old male soccer player undergoes an exercise tolerance test to measure his maximal Oxygen uptake during exercise. Which of the following changes are most likely to occur during exercise?

questions.solution: Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of easy bruising and recurrent nosebleeds over the past 4 months. During the same time period, the patient has felt weak and has had a 10-kg weight loss. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and bruising on the upper and lower extremities in various stages of healing. The spleen is palpated 4 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show anemia and thrombocytopenia. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown.

 

Histologic examination of a bone marrow biopsy in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Neoplastic lymphocytes that stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of gradually worsening facial and lower extremity swelling. She has had a 4-kg weight gain during this time. Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. A 24-hour collection of urine shows 4.0 g of proteinuria. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows dense subepithelial deposits. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-phospholipse A2 receptor antibodies

 

  • This is membranous nephropathy, associated with anti-PLA2R antibodies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Anti-MPO: Seen in microscopic polyangiitis.

 

Option C. Anti-streptolysin O antibodies: Post-streptococcal GN.

 

Option D. Anti-proteinase 3 antibodies: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient?

Cardiac catheterization shows occlusion that has caused a 50% reduction in the diameter of the left circumflex artery. Resistance to blood flow in this vessel has increased by what factor relative to a vessel with no occlusion?

questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of a jaw swelling. His tissue was found to have the presence of t (8;14). The histopathological appearance of the bone marrow aspirate tissue is given in the image. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis for this patient?

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 9-month history of progressive fatigue. Examination shows pallor. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows an irregular, bleeding 3-cm exophytic ulcer in the right colon. Which of the following lesions is the greatest risk factor for this patient's condition?

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease?

questions.text: An investigator is studying the changes that occur in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve of different types of hemoglobin under various conditions. The blood obtained from a male infant shows decreased affinity for 2,3-bisphosphoglyceric acid. Which of the following is the most likely composition of the hemoglobin molecule in this sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 慣2y2

 

  • The blood is from a male infant, and the hemoglobin present in infants is primarily fetal hemoglobin (HbF).
  • HbF consists of two alpha (慣) and two gamma (款) globin chains (慣2款2).
  • HbF has decreased affinity for 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) compared to adult hemoglobin, which increases its oxygen affinity and facilitates oxygen transfer from mother to fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 慣2棺2: Adult hemoglobin (HbA), which has higher affinity for 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. 棺4: Hemoglobin H disease (HbH), composed of 棺4 chains.

 

Option D. 慣2灌2: Hemoglobin A2, a minor component of adult hemoglobin.

questions.text: A decrease in GFR is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting. Upon further investigation, arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following: pH: 7.55, PCO2: 50 mmHg, HCO3-: 44 mmol/L. Given these findings, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin. He started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 mg/dL. The plasma therapeutic range is 1 mg/dL. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long one should wait before resuming the treatment?

questions.text:
A previously healthy 41-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of palpitations and sweating over the past month. Her symptoms typically start after swimming practice and improve after drinking ice tea and eating some candy. She has also had a 5-kg weight gain over the past 3 months. questions.text: A 52-year-old female with diabetes mellitus has experienced a decrease in her HbA1c levels from 7.6 to 6.7 after starting a new oral medication. Laboratory tests show that she has high levels of GIP and GLP-1 and low levels of glucagon. Which of the following oral drugs was most likely administered to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Alogliptin.

Two days ago, he began induction chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisolone, and doxorubicin. Urinalysis shows 3+ blood and abundant amber-colored, rhomboid crystals. Which of the following is most likely to have been effective in preventing this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Alkalinisations of the urine

An x-ray of the chest shows small bilateral reticular opacities, predominantly in the lower lobes. A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on lung biopsy is shown. questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of unintentional weight gain of 5.5 kg and irregular menstrual cycles over the past 2 months. She does not take any medications. Her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases, and violaceous scarring of the abdomen. Early morning serum cortisol levels are elevated and serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is within the reference range after a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata

questions.text: In the figure shown below, mechanism of action of valproate is best represented by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

The mechanism of action of valproate is best represented by A in the diagram, which shows inhibition of GABA transaminase and increased GABA synthesis, leading to increased CNS GABA levels.

 

Mechanism of Valproate

 

  • Valproate increases GABA in the brain by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase (enzyme responsible for GABA degradation), thus reducing breakdown of GABA.
    • Stimulating glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), enhancing GABA synthesis.
  • This is illustrated at the point labeled A in the diagram, where GABA degradation is inhibited and GABA synthesis is promoted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B: Facilitates GABA release (not the main action of valproate).

 

Option C. C: Inhibits GABA reuptake (not the primary valproate effect).

 

Option D. D: Barbiturates and benzodiazepines modulate the GABA-A receptor

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with asthma is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and wheezing for 20 minutes. She is unable to speak more than a few words at a time. Treatment with high-dose continuous inhaled albuterol is begun. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypokalemia

 

Beta-2 agonists like albuterol drive potassium into cells, causing hypokalemia as a common adverse effect during high-dose or continuous treatment. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Miosis: Not associated with beta-2 agonist use. 

 

Option B. Hypoglycemia: Beta-2 agonists can cause hyperglycemia due to glycogenolysis. 

 

Option D. Bradycardia: Beta-2 agonists more commonly cause tachycardia, not bradycardia.

choices.text: Amyloid light chain (AL)

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is more likely to develop in a patient undergoing long-term hemodialysis due to renal failure?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of flank pain, rash, and blood-tinged urine for 1 day. Two months ago, he was started on hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He takes acetaminophen for back pain. Examination shows a generalized, diffuse maculopapular rash. Serum studies show a creatinine concentration of 3.0 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Urinary eosinophils

questions.text: A patient with a mood disorder has been on medication and presents with new-onset liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
